subject: RE: [junit] Unit test for infinite loop
messageBody:
TFP: Transparent Forwarding Pointer?

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Holliday, Donald B. (LNG-SHEP) [mailto:dhollida@my-deja.com]
> Sent: Monday, October 22, 2001 10:31 AM
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: RE: [junit] Unit test for infinite loop
>
>
> What does TFP stand for?
>
> Donald Holliday
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains762@hotmail.com]
> Sent: Sunday, October 21, 2001 6:09 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Unit test for infinite loop
>
>
> > How does one write a unit test that exposes an infinte loop? Well,
> writing
> > one that exposes it isn't hard. How do you expose it with
> out the test
> > hanging?
>
> Suggestion 1: Don't expose the infinite loop. Expose the
> "whatever goes
> wrong because of the infinite loop". That's much easier and equally
> effective at giving you confidence you'll fix the bug. Then
> fix the infinite
> loop. It's extremely unlikely you or someone else will come
> along and put it
> back in there.
>
> Suggestion 2: Do TFP. You can't have an infinite loop for
> long with TFP. :)
>
> JBR.
